RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 

Urban areas in Pakistan are growing rapidly, and demand for improved urban services is 
2. 
increasing.  Current  deficiencies  in  basic  infrastructure  inhibit  economic  growth,  and  severely 
constrain the potential for urban areas to play a more significant role in the country’s economic 
growth.  To  meet  the  growing  pressures  and  demands,  urban  development  has  usually  been 
with few or no environmental controls, and with forms of governance that  cannot begin to meet 
responsibilities. High urban growth, combined with slow urban sector development, has resulted 
in  uncontrolled  urban  sprawl;  deteriorating  urban  environments;  and  deficiencies  in  urban 
services such as  water supply, sewerage systems, drainage, solid waste management, roads, 
and community facilities. The deficiencies have particularly affected the urban poor and caused 
a considerably lower quality of life, including poor health and increased poverty. The incidence 
of poverty increased from 26.6% in fiscal year (FY) 1993 to 32.2% in FY1999. The number of 
poor increased by 12 million during that period.  

The poverty reduction strategy of the Government of Pakistan1 (Government) envisages 
3. 
a  multipronged  strategy  of  reviving  growth, 
improving  governance,  reorienting  public 
expenditures  toward  poverty-reducing  programs,  and  revamping  the  safety  net  system.  The 
Government  is  committed  to  increasing  pro-poor  budgetary  expenditures  by  0.2%  of  gross 
domestic product (GDP) annually, to  4% of GDP in FY2004.2 The Government is implementing 
comprehensive governance reforms, with particular emphasis on enhancing the effectiveness of 
basic social services through its Punjab Local Government Ordinance, 2001 (PLGO2001).  The 
PG’s  poverty  reduction  strategy3  also  emphasizes  the  need  to  implement  broad-based 
governance  reforms  and  improve  social  services  to  address poverty.  To achieve the goals for 
poverty reduction, the Government has requested assistance from the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) in developing the economic potential of low-income urban centers in southern Punjab by 
improving  the  existing  infrastructure,  and  developing  better  institutional  capacity  of  local 
governments.  The  Loan  Fact-Finding  Mission was  undertaken  08–25  July  2003.  This  report is 
based on the consultant’s reports prepared during an ADB-financed technical assistance (TA),4
 
and  the  mission’s  understandings  with  both  the  federal  and  provincial  governments,  and  with 
elected  town  officials  and  community  groups.  Linkages  among  the  project  objectives,  inputs, 
and outputs are shown in the project framework in Appendix 1, and in the chronology of loan-
processing activities in Supplementary Appendix A.

centers. Punjab province is no exception. The urban population is about 25 million, and some

11.5%  of  the  urban  population,  living  in  katchi  abadis..6
  Poverty7  in  Punjab,  as  elsewhere  in 
Pakistan, is increasing. It rose from 25% in FY1993 to 33% in FY1999. Recent data suggests 
that  poverty  increased  further,  both  in  rural  and  urban  areas,  from  FY1999  to  2001.  Poverty

Levels of urban services in Punjab’s urban centers are low, with coverage and service 
6.  
varying  greatly  among  towns.  Although  most  towns  have  water  supply  systems,  only  40%  of 
households are connected to them. Service is limited, water quality is poor, and system losses 
often  exceed  45%.  Service  levels  in  the  sanitation  sector  are  also  low.  Although  many  urban 
centers have piped sewerage systems, most are old, with extremely poor maintenance, limited 
coverage,  and  with  sewage  left  untreated.  Many  households  have  individual  sewage  disposal 
systems, consisting mostly of pit latrines and, to a lesser extent, septic tanks whose overflows 
are discharged into open canals and drainage networks, and infiltrate into groundwater aquifers. 
Drainage systems in the towns depend on open canals that serve as both drainage and sewage 
collection points. Most urban centers have limited solid waste collection systems, but only about 
30%  of  the  waste  is  collected  and  adequately  disposed.  Most  waste,  including  that  from 
hospitals,  is  disposed  in  open  fields  and  unsanitary  dump  sites.  The  urban  road  networks  are 
reasonably  extensive,  but  road  conditions  are  extremely  poor,  with  inadequate  maintenance. 
The  existing  standards  and  provision  of  infrastructure  in  the  urban  centers  are  generally 
insufficient to support sustained human development and economic growth. 
 
To address the urban problems and institutional shortcomings, particularly in delivery of 
7. 
basic  services  and  facilities  to  the  general  public,  the  Government  has  initiated  a  program  to 
devolve  power  and  responsibility,  based  on  a  bottom-up  methodology  that  is  people-centered 
and oriented to customer services. The devolution program, implemented on 14 August 2000, is 
based  on  five  fundamentals:  devolution  of  political  power,  decentralization  of  administrative

C. 

Special Features 

36. 
This is the first ADB-supported investment project to make concerted efforts to align its 
scope and focus, and institutional and financing modalities,  with the new governance structure 
under  PLGO2001.  The  Project  supports  PG  and  tehsil  authorities  for  adoption  of  the 
arrangements envisaged under PLGO2001. The Project has a number of special features with 
respect to devolution, the role of the Provincial Finance Commission (PFC), and collateral policy 
actions.  The  design  seeks  to  ensure  that  execution  arrangements  with  LGRD  do  not 
compromise the devolved authorities of the TMAs. TMA project implementation follows the spirit 
of PLGO2001, shifting from vertical to horizontal programming.  It particularly offers assistance 
to the transition from vertical province-driven programs to programs that the TMAs should fully 
carry out, with the necessary autonomy in the true spirit of devolution.  

37. 
In  the  past,  a  top-down  approach  was  used  in  project  preparation,  but  this  project  was 
designed  in  close  collaboration  with  beneficiaries,  NGOs,  and  TMAs.  Besides  extensive 
meetings  in  the  field  with  these  groups,  three  consultative  workshops  were  organized  at  the 
inception,  interim,  and  final  stages  of  the  project  preparatory  technical  assistance  (PPTA).    In 
the final workshop, the TMAs endorsed the proposed scope and implementation arrangements 
of  the  Project.  The  proposed  establishment  of  PUs  at  each  TMA,  and  TMA  and  beneficiary 
involvement in the planning and implementation of the Project, offer an opportunity to the TMAs 
to  independently  implement  the  Project  in  line  with  their  needs,  and  within  the  spirit  of 
PLGO2001. 

38. 
In most Punjab slums, more than 70% of the population lives below the poverty line, and 
women have less-skilled and less-remunerative jobs than men. Enhancement of women’s roles 
by providing skills training to increase  their incomes is an important facet of the Project. Local 
NGOs  will  implement  the  skills  training  programs  at  facilities  made  available  by  the  Project. 
Professional  training  will  enable  women  to  set  up  small  enterprises  and  become  involved  in 
income-generating  activities,  thus  contributing  to  their  household  incomes.  The  training, 
savings,  and  access  to  credit  facilities  such  as  the  ADB-assisted  Microfinance  Sector 
Development  Program,  is  also  expected  to  help  increase  the  income  and  confidence  of  poor 
women  in  slum  areas.  Of  equal  importance,  the  Project  will  increase  awareness  on  health, 
sanitation,  and  improved  community  participation,  through  its  community  development 
component.

mobilization  has  been  limited  by  weak  institutional  capacity  of  local  governments  and  the  low 
willingness of the general public to pay for services.  

63. 
PG and TMAs have agreed to take necessary steps to increase the TMAs' revenue base 
in  a  sustainable  manner,  and  enhance  and  stabilize  the  TMAs’  institutional  capacities  and 
organizational setups in the light of gap analysis undertaken during the PPTA in comparing the 
PLGO2001 and existing status of TMAs. This involves (i) making adjustments necessary to fully 
align  the  TMAs’  organizational  and  institutional  structures  in  accordance  with  PLGO2001 
requirements;  (ii)  ensuring  TMA  compliance  in  the  conduct  of  business  of  the tehsil councils; 
administration of data and information management related to base maps; updating of registers 
and  schedules;  improvement  of  procedures  for  budgeting,  accounting,  billing,  revenue 
collection, and financial management; and essentials of public disclosure and transparency; and 
(iii) rationalizing the existing low levels of water tariff and implement them incrementally to cover 
O&M  of  the  existing  infrastructure  and  ensure  sustainability  of  future  development  under  the 
Project. TMAs will update consumer databases and prepare an action plan of financial reforms, 
including more efficient collection of water and sewerage tariffs, and incremental tariff revisions 
with  improved  service  delivery  over  a  specified  time  frame.  All  of  these  measures  must be 
satisfactory  to  ADB.  Project sustainability depends on these  reforms and adjustments, so PG 
 

 16 

and  TMAs  have  agreed  to  make  action  on  them  a  prerequisite  for  TMA  entry  into  the  Project 
(Appendix  5).  Considering  that  TMA  commitment  alone  will  not  be  a  sufficient  basis  for  a 
successful  and  sustainable  investment  program,  PG  has  agreed  to  take  policy  actions  to 
support the TMAs in accordance with PLGO2001 (Appendix 6).   

IV. 

PROJECT BENEFITS, IM PACTS, AND RISKS 

A. 

Benefits and Impacts 

64. 
General. The Project will improve the living conditions of about 3.6 million urban residents, 
mostly poor, through improved delivery of basic municipal services. The Project will (i) increase 
sewerage and drainage service coverage; (ii) provide safe water to the poor; and thus (iii) improve 
public  health;  (iv) provide  treated  wastewater  for  use  in  agriculture;  (v) reduce  environmental 
degradation  and  natural  resource  depletion;  (vi) strengthen  institutional  capabilities  in  urban 
planning  and  management,  and  in  overall  governance;  (vii) generate efficiency gains, reducing 
distribution  leakage  and  electricity  costs  in  the  water  supply  sector;  (vii) improve cost recovery 
through  better  service  delivery;  (ix) enhance  growth  of  the  urban  economy;  (x)  create  local 
employment; and (xi) reduce urban poverty. 

65. 
The effectiveness and sustainability of improvements will be reinforced by efforts aimed at 
community  development,  institutional  strengthening,  and  revenue  improvement  in  the  project 
towns. These efforts will also lead to a stronger sense of belonging at local level; and increased 
capacities  of  the  newly  created  TMAs  to  perform  their  duties  more  effectively,  especially  in 
provision of O&M for existing, rehabilitated, and new infrastructure facilities. 

66. 
Community  involvement.  The  Project  will  encourage  and  strengthen  collective  action 
within  low-income  and  under-serviced  localities.  A  main  objective  of  this  work  will  be  to  make 
infrastructure  investment  by  TMAs  more  responsive  to  demands  of  low-income  groups, more 
inclusive,  more  sustainable,  and  more  cost-effective  than  they  were  through  supply-driven 
approaches.  A secondary  objective  will  be  to  empower  low -income  groups  by  giving  them  the 
capability for collective action through CBOs, and by forming functional links among communities, 
CBOs, union councils (UCs), and TMAs. 

67. 
Public-private  and  community  partnerships.  Private  sector  involvement  will  be 
fostered  and  strengthened.  The  TMAs  will  be  urged  and  assisted  to  define  and  offer 
opportunities  for private sector activities, mainly in the transport, recycling, and composting of 
solid  waste;  and  in  municipal  slaughterhouse  and  wastewater  treatment  plant  operations.  The 
potential for community partnerships in the delivery of urban services, the form of participation 
developed, and the role of each partner will be influenced by the complexity and the degree to 
which the community feels ownership of the work . The array of services (e.g., water, sanitation, 
solid waste, wastewater treatment), the scale of these services (primary, secondary, or tertiary), 
and the stage of their implementation (planning, construction, or maintenance) create a range of 
opportunities for participation. Therefore, service delivery will be disaggregated, to consider the 
potential  roles  of  partners  at  different  levels  and  to  integrate  them  into  a  practical 
implementation proposal. 

Poverty reduction.  Socioeconomic surveys in the project towns show that 57% of the 
68. 
sample  households  live  on  a  monthly  income  of  less  than  Rs.5,000  ($85),  which  is  about  the 
current  poverty  line.  Urban  poverty  in  the  project  towns  is  multifaceted,  ranging  from  a  lack  of 
employment  to  deficiencies  in  basic  urban  services  such  as  water  and  sewerage  and  solid 
waste  disposal,  to  substandard  housing.  The  combination  of  a  shortage  of  good  quality  water 
with  inadequate  sewerage  systems  has  adversely  affected  public  health  and  the  urban 
environment.  

The  Project  will  provide  water  to  the  poor  through  piped  distribution  systems  or 
69. 
communal water points. For sanitation and wastewater management, sewerage pipe networks 

 17 

will  be  rehabilitated  and  expanded  to  low-income  areas,  together  with  simple  wastewater 
treatment plants. Expected benefits include improvements in public hygiene and health in  low-
income  areas,  and  reduced  pollution  of  groundwater  and  surface  water  in  the  project  towns. 
Improved public health will contribute to a more productive labor force. Employment generated 
in  civil  works  will  contribute  directly  and  positively  to  poverty  reduction.  Improved  solid  waste 
management  and  recycling,  preferably  with  private  sector  involvement,  will  also  create 
employment for the urban poor. Use of treated effluent for irrigation will help improve agriculture 
production and income for poor farmers. Appendix 11 shows a summary poverty reduction and 
social strategy.  

Gender. A large part of the Project’s benefits will accrue to women. Women’s time and 
70. 
energy  will  be  saved  by  provision  of  water  supply  to  households,  whether  through  pipes  or 
communal water points. Women will also enjoy a large part of the benefits of improved sewerage 
because (i) women spend more time within the residential neighborhoods than men and thus, will 
benefit more from improved hygiene there; and (ii) women are traditionally charged with the care 
of sick family members and will thus benefit more from reduced illness.  The Project will address 
gender  issues  by  (i)  strengthening  the  role  of  women  councilors  in  municipal  governance;  (ii) 
involving  women  groups  in  community-level  project  activities;  (iii)  including  women  of  local 
government  institutions  in  training  activities;  and  (iv)  conducting  community  training  and 
mobilizational campaigns for project beneficiaries in the wards at the UC level to ensure active 
participation  of  women.  Supplementary  Appendix  F  gives  a  gender  strategy,  which  PG  has 
approved. 

Enhancing the role of women by providing skills training to increase their income levels 
71. 
is  an  important  project  facet.  Skills  training  will  enable  women to set up small enterprises and 
become  involved  in  income-generating  activities  that  contribute  to  household  incomes.  The 
training,  savings,  and  access  to  credit  facilities  such  as  the  ADB-assisted  Microfinance 
Development  Program  are  expected  to  help  increase  the  incomes  and  confidence  of  poor 
women in the slums.  

72.  Minorities  and  indigenous  people.  The  cultural  and  ethnic  diversity  of  people  in  the 
project  towns  was  reviewed  as  part  of  the  socioeconomic  survey  during  the  PPTA.  Detailed 
analysis  showed  no  evidence  of  negative  impacts  on  minorities  or  indigenous  people.  Some 
households  of  a  religious  minority  whose  members  work  as  municipal  sweepers  are  in  areas 
that  lack  water  supply  and  sanitation  facilities.  The  Project  will  address  their  needs through (i) 
provision of public water stand posts in their neighborhoods, (ii) improving access to sewerage 
systems,  (iii)  at  least  30%  employment  of  women  in  the  community-based  program  for  solid 
waste  management,  (iv)  participation  of  men  and  women  community  leaders  in  the  users’ 
groups, and (v) employment of labor from this community in civil works. 

73. 
Economic  and  financial  benefits.  Economic  and  financial  analyses  of  the  proposed 
subprojects  were  undertaken  in  accordance  with  ADB's  Framework  for  the  Economic  and 
Financial  Appraisal  of  Urban  Development  Sector  Projects   (Appendixes  12  and  13).  The 
economic  benefits  identified  were  based  on  each  subproject  in  21  project  towns.  Economic 
internal  rates  of  return  (EIRRs)  were  prepared  for  18  sewerage  subprojects,  7  water  supply 
subprojects, 12 slaughterhouses, 21 solid waste management subprojects, and 13 subprojects 
for upgrading of road links in low-income communities. The benefits include significant poverty 
alleviation and improvements in living conditions, particularly in health and hygiene of the largely 
poor  urban  populations.  This  will  be  mainly  through  sewer  connections  and  improved  solid 
waste collection and disposal. Wastewater treatment will provide additional water for agricultural 
production, and reduce environmental damage.  
 
74. 
Health and nonincremental benefits of water supply subprojects include (i) resource cost 
savings  for  users  obtaining  water  from  secondary  sources,  which  will  be  contaminated  if  the 
water  supply  subproject  is  not  implemented;  and  (ii)  availability  of  water  that  is  now  being 

 

 18 
wasted,  after  improvement  of  facilities  under  the  Project.22  Incremental  benefits  include 
additional  water  sales  to  meet  suppressed  or  increased  demand  of  existing  customers,  and 
additional sales to new customers who will be connected to the piped network. These benefits 
are based on customers’ willingness to pay. 

75.  
The financial internal rate of returns (FIRRs) for subprojects range from 6% to 33% for 6 
water  supply  subprojects,  5%  to  30%  for  12  slaughterhouses,  and  11%  to  55%  for  21  solid 
waste  subprojects.  The  incremental  costs  of  some  sub-components  will  be  quite  low  as 
compared  to  the  incremental  revenues  which  result  in  high  FIRRs.  The  FIRRs  exceed  the 
weighted average cost of capital, which is about 5%, demonstrating that the Project is financially 
viable at proposed tariff levels. Testing of the switching values and sensitivity indicators showed 
the subprojects to be financially viable under adverse cost and revenue scenarios. 

76.  
The EIRR calculation was undertaken in constant 2003 prices using the domestic price 
numeraire,  since  the  outputs  are  nontradable  in  nature.  Economic  costs,  excluding  taxes  and 
market distortions, are converted using a standard conversion factor of 0.85. The EIRRs in the 
project  towns  for  water  supply  subprojects  range  from  17.3%  for  Rohjan  to  45.2%  in  Multan; 
EIRRS  for  sewerage  range  from  13%  in  Jahanian  to  35.5%  in  Yazman;  for  solid  waste,  from 
16.1% in Hasilpur to 57.9% in Khanewal; for slaughterhouses, from 12.2% in Rohjan to 57.4% 
in Ahmadpur East; and link roads in low-income areas, from 14.4% in Qadirpur Ran to 51.1% in 
Jahanian.    Switching  values  and  sensitivity  indicators  were  tested,  and  standard  and  project-
specific sensitivity cases were conducted on key variables, using 20% increases in capital and 
O&M costs and 30% decreases in willingness to pay and number of households benefited. Most 
subprojects  were  found  economically  viable  under  adverse  cost:  benefit  scenarios,  except in 
smaller  towns  with  lower  beneficiary  populations  and  lower  economic  activity.  Supplementary 
Appendix G gives results of the economic analysis of each subproject in 21 project towns. 

77.   Environmental  impact.  Initial  Environmental  Examinations  (IEEs) were carried out on 
all the subprojects and components as part of the PPTA. The IEEs concluded that the proposed 
subprojects  and  components  will  have  no  significant  adverse  impacts on the environment and 
consequently,  no  subproject  will  require  an  environmental  impact  assessment.  In  conformity 
with  environmental  management  practices,  the  Project  will  develop  and  operationalize  an 
environmental monitoring and management plan. PG will ensure that environmental standards 
prescribed by the Punjab Environmental Protection Agency are met. Supplementary Appendix H 
gives a summary IEE.

Urbanization and Urban Infrastructure 

URBAN SECTOR ANALYSIS 

1. 
Rapid  urbanization  in  Pakistan  has  overtaxed  the  abilities  of  government  institutions  to 
provide  adequate  infrastructure  and  urban  services.  Much  of  the  urban  growth  has  been 
uncontrolled  and  unplanned,  because  of  the  absence  of  effective  planning  and  enforcement 
tools,  and  insufficient  development  of  human  resources.  Most  towns  and  cities  lack  plans  for 
controlled  urban  development,  and  for  linkage  between  the  development  of  new  housing  and 
commercial  or  industrial  areas.  Most  urban  areas  have  not  developed  the  infrastructure  and 
urban services needed to support such urban growth and expansion. 

2.    Urban  areas  suffer  from  various  deficiencies  in  infrastructure.  Town  centers  generally 
have  most  required  elements  of  physical  infrastructure, including roads, markets, bus stands, 
water  supply  systems  without  community  involvement,  sewerage  systems,  and  solid  waste 
collection systems. Some systems, especially roads, markets, and bus stands, suffer capacity 
problems because urban populations and commercial activities in the town centers have grown 
to a level beyond that for which they were designed. As a result, commercial activities spill over 
into the streets—which are already overburdened by a vehicle traffic volume far higher than for 
which they were designed. 

Systems for water supply, sewerage, and solid waste collection suffer greatly from poor 
3.   
operations and maintenance (O&M). The provincial government often designed and constructed 
the  water  supply  systems,  then  turned  them  over  to  the  local  government  for  O&M.  Local 
government then must somehow handle gaps between the design of those systems and the real 
consumer  demand.  The  gaps  are  often  considerable,  and  led  to  poor  utilization  of  those 
systems,  resulting  in  poor  cost  rec overy  and  the  need  for  permanent  subsidies  from  local 
government budgets. The collection and disposal of municipal solid waste is mostly poor, with 
no  participation  of  local  communities,  nongovernment  organizations  (NGOs),  or  the  private 
sector.  Uncollected  waste  causes  adverse  environmental  effects,  such  as  bad  odors  and  the 
breeding of flies. Poor collection and removal of solid waste also leads to the clogging of sewer 
lines,  a  major  problem  of  urban  infrastructure  systems.  Blocked  sewer  lines  make  household 
sewage collection ineffective, and cause ponding of sewage in lanes and streets. This leads to 
damage  to  private  and  public  property,  disruption  of  traffic,  breeding  of  mosquitoes  and  other 
pests,  and  infiltration  of  sewage  into  shallow  groundwater—which  leads  to  serious  health 
problems,  because  most  households  use  the  shallow  groundwater,  through  hand  or  motor 
pumps, as their main water sources. Some basic services are totally missing in peripheral and 
under-serviced areas of most towns. There, people use shallow, brackish water, or take water 
from public standposts where available. Sewerage systems are nonexistent, and sewage often 
flows  uncontrolled  into  depressions  where  it  ponds.  There  is  often  no  organized  collection  of 
municipal solid waste. 

B. 

Urban Sector Institutions 

4.    With  the  Punjab  Local  Government  Ordinance  2001  (PLGO2001),  responsibility  for 
delivery of municipal urban services, and for environmental improvement, rests mainly with the 
tehsil  municipal  administration  (TMAs).  Some  responsibility  rests  with  the  lowest  level  of  local 
government,  the  union  councils  which  are  charged  with  community  development  and  related 
tasks; and with district governments, which handle affairs related to government land as well as 
the health and education sectors.  

5.   
Implementation  of  the  PLGO2001  has  considerably  reduced  the  previously  dominating 
roles of provincial agencies, especially of the Housing, Urban Development, and Public Health

C. 

Government Policies and Plans 

9.   
Pakistan’s  national  urban  and  housing  policy  is  reflected  in  the  Ten  Year  Perspective 
Development  Plan  2001–2011,  which  describes  the  main  urban  problems  as  (i) environmental 
degradation,  mushrooming  of  katchi  abadis,  and  breakdown  of  infrastructure  and  municipal 
services;  (ii) lack  of  vision,  inadequate  institutional  setup,  and  weak  financial  bases,  (iii) a 
backlog  of  2 million  housing  units,  in  addition  to  the  2.3  million  units  that  are  structurally 
obsolete;  and  (iv) the  absence  of  a  housing  finance  institution  to  provide  affordable loans for 
house construction. 

10.  
The plan envisages the following strategies for urban development: (i) strengthening the 
role  of  local  organizations  in  planning,  determining  needs,  preparing  action  plans,  and 
augmenting  capacities  for  water  supply  and  sanitation  services;  (ii)  developing  satellite, 
intermediate or  secondary,    and  industrial  towns  as  employment  centers;  (iii) preparing or 
updating master plans; (iv) implementing the national policy on  katchi abadis; and (v) upgrading 
katchi abadis and slums through integrated packages for area improvement. 

11.  
For water supply and sanitation, the plan envisages providing water supply services to 
an additional 55 million persons (28 million rural and 27 million urban), thus increasing national 
service coverage from 63% to 84%; and sanitation facilities for an additional 54 million persons 
(26 million rural and 28 million urban), thus increasing national sanitation coverage from 39% to 
63%.  Private  sector  participation  in  water  supply  for  major  cities  will  be  encouraged, and the 
institutional capacity of water supply and sanitation agencies will be upgraded.

Contribution of Subsector to Poverty Reduction in Pakistan 

Pakistan faces the twin challenges of reviving economic growth and reducing poverty. The incidence of poverty 
in Pakistan has risen slowly but steadily during the 1990s, from 29.3% in 1993–1994 to 32.2% in 1998–1999. 
Poverty in urban area is estimated as 22.4%. Only 63% of the country’s population has access to safe drinking 
water (83% in urban areas, and 53% in rural areas). Proper sanitation facilities are available to only 39% of the 
population (59% in urban areas, and 27% in rural areas). Poor access to water supply and sanitation is often 
associated with poor health. Consolidated (federal and provincial) expenditures on water supply and sanitation 
have actually decreased over the past 5 years, both in nominal terms and as a percentage of gross domestic 
product  (GDP).  Consolidated  public  expenditures  on  water  supply  and  sanitation  (public  health  engineering) 
have  come  down  from  Rs6.3  billion  in  1995–1996  (0.30%  of  GDP)  to  Rs4.5  billion  in  2000–2001 (0.13% of 
GDP). As a result, extension of public water supply and sanitation facilities has not kept pace with the growing 
needs of the rising population. 

Poverty incidence also varies significantly among provinces. Punjab province has the second-highest incidence 
of  poverty,  after  North  West  Frontier  province,  in  both  rural  and  urban  areas.  Within  Punjab,  poverty  differs 
considerably  from  south  to  north.  The  level  of  economic  development  and  income  in  southern  Punjab  is 
generally lower than in northern Punjab, where a great deal of development efforts and investments, especially 
industrial  investments,  have  been  concentrated  in  recent  years.  Urban  areas  of  northern  Punjab  have  the 
country’s lowest poverty level (13%), but urban poverty in southern Punjab is the highest in Pakistan (35% in 
FY1999,  up  from  28%  in  1993).  Poverty  in  southern  Punjab  is  largely  caused  by  limitations  to  growth  of  the 
agricultural sector, which is in turn related to an increasing shortage of irrigation water. This rural poverty spills 
over  into  the  towns  and  cities,  where  more  than  half  of  the  populations  are  often  classified  as  poor,  suffering 
from a lack of employment, low household incomes, and lack of basic services.  

The  Poverty  Partnership  Agreement  between  the  Government  of  Pakistan  and  the  Asian  Development  Bank 
(ADB) reflects Government’s vision for poverty reduction and key priorities of the ADB’s Country Strategy and 
Program. ADB’s country strategy for Pakistan emphasizes water supply, sanitation and urban development, and 
the need to target the poor to reduce both poverty and inequalities. The Government has agreed that long-term 
poverty reduction requires sharper focus on good governance, allocation for social sectors, and improving basic 
social  services  to  enhance  human  development.  The  Poverty  Partnership  Agreement  als o  focuses  on 
attainment of the millennium development goals (MDGs). ADB aims to help the Government make devolution a 
success and improve service delivery and municipal services, with particular focus on services for the poor.   

The  Project  will  foster  institutional  development  of  the  local  government’s  tehsil  (subdistrict)  municipal 
administrations (TMAs) in Punjab, and will finance infrastructure improvements in 21 project towns that focus on 
water  supply,  sewerage  and  wastewater  management,  solid  waste  management,  slaughterhouses,  and 
programs on hygiene and environmental awareness. The Project aims to improve living conditions and health 
status  of  the  people  in  project  towns.  Access  to  safe  drinking  water,  improved  sanitation,  and  improved 
environmental  quality  will  reduce  vulnerability  to  environmental  hazards  for  the  poor  communities.  Improved 
quantity  and  quality  of  domestic  water  supply  and  sanitation  facilities  will  reduce  morbidity  and  mortality, 
especially  for  young  children.    The  availability  of  safe  drinking  water  supplies  will  reduce  water-carrying time, 
which will benefit mainly women and girls. A better environment in the urban areas will improve the quality of life 
and  productive  capacity  of  the  residents,  many  of  whom  are  poor.  Improved  ins titutional  capacity  of  local 
government  will  provide  opportunities  for  effective  local  planning,  improved  institution  and  financial 
management, and collaboration between local people and local government officials to ensure sustainability of 
urban services  infrastructure in small towns.

A socioeconomic survey in the project towns indicated that 57% of the sample households live on a monthly 
income  of  less  than  Rs5,000  ($85),  which  is  about  the  current  poverty  line.  The  highest  percentage  of  poor

largest  group  is  unemployed.  Urban  poverty  in  the  project  towns  is  multifaceted,  ranging  from  a  lack  of 
employment  to  deficiencies  in  basic  urban  services  such  as  water,  sewerage,  and  solid  waste  disposal,  to 
substandard housing. 

A  socioeconomic  survey  in  22  prospective  project  towns  showed  that  about  92%  of  the  sample  households 
have access to piped water, and 8% use public standpipes. But the water supply is intermittent, and delivery is 
mostly  less  than  50 liters/person  per  day.  Also,  the  water  quality  often  falls  below  the  standards  of  the  World 
Health  Organization  for  drinking  water,  mainly  because  of  bacteriological  contamination  as  a  result  of  poor 
sanitation  facilities  and,  in  some  locations,  because  of  salinity.  About  84%  of  the  sample  households  have 
toilets inside their houses, while 16% must defecate in open spaces such as along river banks or drainage or 
irrigation canals, or in empty plots. 

The coverage of sewerage systems, which are often combined with storm water drainage systems, in the urban 
areas  is  limited.  Final  treatment  of  sewage  is  inadequate  in  all  project  towns.  Only  25%  of  the  sample 
households have access to adequate sewerage systems. The other households suffer from various degree of 
environmental pollution in their neighborhoods, through the disposal of wastewater in open drains, and flooding 
of such wastewater in the residential neighborhoods. There is no wastewater treatment plant in the project area, 
and raw sewage is disposed in irrigation channels or open fields.  

The  combined  shortage  of  quality  water  and  inadequate  sewerage  adversely  affects  public  health  and  urban 
environments.  The  lack  of  adequate  water  supply  facilities  and  sewerage  systems  is  a  particular  burden  on 
women  because  women  are  mainly  responsible  for  water  collection,  for  family  health  maintenance,  and  for 
caring for sick family.  

The  Project  will  provide  water  to  poor  communities  through  piped  distribution  systems  and  communal  water 
points.  The  component  for  sanitation  and  was tewater  management  will  provide  expanded  sewerage  pipe 
networks to low-income areas, along with simple wastewater treatment plants. The systems will be designed to 
give the urban poor adequate access to improved sanitation. Expected benefits are public hygiene and health 
improvement in low-income areas, and reduced pollution of groundwater and surface water in the project towns. 
Improved public health will contribute to a more productive labor force. Employment generation in civil works will 
be another direct positive contribution of the Project to poverty reduction. Improved solid waste management 
and recycling, preferably with private sector involvement, will also create employment for the urban poor. Use of 
treated effluent for irrigation will improve agricultural production and income for poor farmers.  

The Project will also ensure that poor households of low-caste communities have access to basic services and 
resources. Some households of a religious minority whose members work as municipal sweepers live in areas 
that lack water supply and sanitation facilities more than in other project towns. The Project will address their 
needs through (i) provision of public water stand posts in their neighborhoods; (ii) improving access to sewerage 
systems;  (iii)  at  least  30%  employment  of  women  in  the  community-based  program  for  solid  waste 
management; (iv) participation of women and men community leaders in the users’ groups; (v) participation of 
women  and  men  in  environmental  awareness,  health,  and  hygiene  campaigns; and (vi) employment of labor 
from this  community in civil works.

D. 

Solid Waste 

11. 
The  Project  will  focus  on  the  development  of  landfill  sites  in  towns  that  have  no  landfill 
facilities, the purchase of equipment for use in garbage collection and disposal, and incinerators 
for  disposal  of  hospital  wastes.  The  towns  now  have  systems  for  garbage  collection  from 
households, but only about 60% of garbage generated is actually collected. The remaining 40% of 
uncollected garbage finds its way into storm drains and sewer lines, clogging them and eventually 
causing  high  flooding  incidence.34  The  major  economic  benefit  identified  for  the  Project  is  the 
residents’  willingness  to  pay  for  clean  and  efficient  collection  and  disposal  of  their  waste.  The 
socioeconomic  survey  conducted  in  each  town  showed  that  75%  to  85%  of  total  residents 
expressed  a  willingness  to  pay  of  from  PRs20  to  PRs50  for  low-income  households,  to  from 
PRs50 to PRs100 for high-income households.  

E. 

Road Links 

12. 
The proposed road links are to improve access of low-income residents to the education, 
health, and livelihood opportunities in the town centers. All of the current road links, mostly narrow 
lanes,  are  in  poor  condition  with  low  vehicular  traffic  volume.  Improvement  of  the  road  links  is 
expected to enhance economic activity in low-income areas, resulting in improved land values. 

13. 
Benefits identified include increased land values and savings in vehicle operating costs for 
low-volume  traffic.35  The  increase  in  land  values  was  used  to  estimate  the  benefits  of  the 
improved roads. It was assumed that about 100 meters on each side  of the roads will be affected 
directly, but land value will actually increase, because of enhanced pedestrian mobility pedestrian 
and  increased  nonmotorized  traffic,  in  only  20%  of  the  affected  area.  The  increased  economic 
activity  will  be  through  the  proliferation  of  commercial  activity  along  the  road.  Because  these 
roads  lead  to  low-income  communities,  the  increase  in  land  values  was  assumed  to  be  1% 
throughout the evaluation period.

Results 

16.

be  12%.  Standard  sensitivity  tests  were  conducted  for  a  10%  increase  in  capital  and  operating 
costs and a 10% reduction in subproject benefits, and a worst-case scenario of a combined 10% 
decrease in benefits and 10% increase in costs. Additional project-specific sensitivity cases have 
been undertaken to determine the impact of changes in key variables on subproject viability and 
include:  (i)  a  1-year  delay  in  project  benefits,  20%  decrease  in  willingness  to  pay,  and  20% 
decline in number of households served due to lower operational efficiencies for subprojects for 
sewerage, water supply, and solid waste management; (ii) for slaughterhouses, a 20% decrease 
in households affected by meat spoilage; and (iii) for road links, a 20% decrease in area affected 
and  a  15%  decrease  in  assumed  land  values.  Some  subprojects  in  smaller  towns  became 
marginally  feasible  under  the  worst-case  scenario  and  worst-case  sensitivity  tests  on  key 
variables. Resulting EIRRs are most sensitive to  decline in project benefits. Switching values and 
sensitivity indicators were likewise calculated and are presented in Table A12.1 to Table A12.5. 38
